predictions.reasoning: DUPLICATE CLOSURE. Glucksberg (CONTRIBUTOR) explicitly flags PR #6797 as implementing the same fix. Although heybeaux attempts to differentiate the implementations, matskevich's comment reveals #6797 is already running in production with 550+ validated events. This constitutes a superseded/duplicate scenario. The pattern P-2-0 (maintainer/member duplicate closure) combined with production validation of the competing PR (#6797) strongly signals this PR will not merge independently. The follow-up discussion about extended lifecycle (message:preprocessed) does not override the duplicate triage assessment. sebslight's final comment appears to be a closure action.

FIRST-TIME CONTRIBUTOR, MEDIUM-SIZED FEATURE, NO HUMAN REVIEWER ENGAGEMENT. Pattern P-2-8: medium-sized feature PRs from first-time contributors with no maintainer approval or label do not reliably merge. Author has 0 prior PRs (0% merge rate). PR has 13 files (M size). Only automated Greptile review present; zero human reviewer comments, zero human approvals, zero maintainer comments. No maintainer label, no trusted-contributor label. Despite focused scope and tests present in files (grouped-render.test.ts, tool-cards.test.ts, chat.test.ts), the absence of human engagement combined with first-time contributor status and no maintainer signal makes merge unlikely.

FIRST-TIME CONTRIBUTOR, XS SIZE, ZERO HUMAN ENGAGEMENT. Pattern P-2-9: first-time contributors with XS-sized PRs that have only automated reviews and no human reviewer engagement are unlikely to merge. Author has 0 prior PRs (0% merge rate). Only Greptile automated review present. Zero human comments, zero human approvals, zero maintainer engagement. While scope is narrow (2 files, XS size), the complete absence of human validation combined with first-time contributor status and no maintainer signal makes merge unlikely. The PR addresses legitimate Swift 6 concurrency issues, but lacks the human reviewer endorsement needed for low-context first-time contributors.

AUTOMATED TRIAGE CLOSURE — EXCEEDS FILE LIMIT. Pattern P-2-14 applies: PRs with >100 files changed when automated triage bot comment is present citing file count as closure trigger are terminal non-merge signals. PR has 274 files changed (only 100 shown). clawdinator (CONTRIBUTOR automated triage bot) explicitly closes the PR stating '262 files found, 100 file limit' and 'triage pressure'. This is a deterministic closure signal. The PR description title ('Claude/review self aware architecture 3 ynpt') suggests low-quality/placeholder content. 0% merge rate author with XL-size PR and automated triage closure = certain non-merge.

FIRST-TIME CONTRIBUTOR, ZERO HUMAN ENGAGEMENT, FAILING CI SIGNAL. Pattern P-2-22: first-time contributors with no human reviewer engagement and failing CI are unlikely to merge, even with narrow scope (XS). Author has 1 prior PR with 0% merge rate. PR has 7 files but only XS/narrow scope is claimed. Greptile comment flags critical Swift 6 concurrency issue: 'ISO8601DateFormatter isn't thread-safe' and unsafe marking suggests latent bugs. Zero human comments, zero human approvals, zero maintainer engagement. Despite being a fix PR, the combination of first-time contributor status, concurrent safety bug discovery, and zero human validation makes merge unlikely. Author needs human reviewer to validate the fix.

DUPLICATE OF #8977. FIRST-TIME CONTRIBUTOR, 0% MERGE RATE, ZERO HUMAN ENGAGEMENT. PR #8980 appears to be a duplicate/resubmission of #8977 (same title 'fix(macos): add scrolling to Permissions settings', same author kkkkk0cool, created 3 minutes after #8977, overlapping files MenuBar.swift and PermissionsSettings.swift). Author has now submitted 2 PRs, both with 0% merge rate. Only 2 files in #8980 (subset of #8977's 7 files). Zero comments, zero human reviews, zero maintainer engagement. Pattern P-3-1 (supersession): this appears to be a duplicate submission that would be superseded by whichever PR (#8977 or #8980) is reviewed first. Given the pattern of duplicate submission and zero human validation, both should be treated as unlikely to merge.

AUTHOR SELF-CLOSES AS NON-ISSUE. arosstale (CONTRIBUTOR) explicitly closes the PR stating: 'test-only PR with no linked issue... not addressing a specific user-reported problem.' This is a terminal closure signal. Additionally, Glucksberg flags this as part of a consolidation discussion (#9846), indicating organizational triage. Although author has 33 prior PRs, this particular PR is test-only coverage with no issue linkage, which doesn't meet merge criteria for the project. Author's own closure comment overrides any historical merge rate consideration.

FIRST-TIME CONTRIBUTOR, XS SIZE, BUG FIX, TESTS PRESENT. Positive signals: XS size (3 files), has tests (VoiceWakeRuntimeTests.swift), narrow focused scope (CJK trigger crash fix), CHANGELOG included. Negative signals: first-time contributor (0% merge rate), zero human comments/reviews (only emoji comment from GEJXD non-identified user), zero maintainer engagement, no maintainer label. The PR addresses a real bug (Voice Wake crash on CJK transcripts) with test coverage, which puts it above the typical first-time contributor baseline. However, complete absence of human reviewer validation and maintainer engagement keeps confidence moderate. Pattern P-2-9 would normally apply (XS + automated only + first-time), but presence of explicit tests for the bug fix raises probability slightly above baseline.

AUTHOR SELF-CLOSES AS DUPLICATE. xinhuagu (CONTRIBUTOR) explicitly closes: 'duplicate of existing EPIPE fix PRs (#7117, #13414).' This is a terminal closure signal per Pattern P-2-0 (duplicate closure). Author acknowledges the overlap and self-dismisses the PR. Greptile comment flags additional EPIPE risk in installLaunchAgent, but this doesn't change the duplicate status of the current PR. First-time contributor with 1 file change, but the duplicate closure is deterministic. No merge will occur.

AUTOMATED TRIAGE CLOSURE — EXCEEDS LABEL LIMIT. Pattern P-2-14 applies: PRs with >20 labels where automated triage bot comment is present citing label count as closure trigger are terminal non-merge signals. openclaw-barnacle (automated triage bot) closes the PR 10 times explicitly stating: 'more than 20 labels, which usually means the branch is too noisy.' PR has 31 labels (20 channel labels + 10 extension labels + size label). This is a deterministic automated closure. Regardless of author history (battman21: 26 prior PRs, 7.7% merge rate), the automated triage closure overrides all other signals. The PR touches multiple channels and extensions (dangerous per AGENTS.md guidance), but the label-count triage closure is terminal.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with XS scope and automated review only. Member comment 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen' signals closure decision. Author explicitly closes this PR in favor of a renamed-branch PR (#11577). Comment states 'Closing this PR in favor of the new one' — this is supersession by author's own action. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with medium scope (5 files, M-adjacent size). Maintainer (sebslight) comment appears to be closing statement. Greptile identified P2-level concern regarding event object mutation impacting idempotency. Pattern P-3-10 applies: first-time contributors with medium-sized feature PRs and no maintainer approval/label do not reliably merge even with community discussion. No approval signal present. Closing statement from maintainer suggests non-merge outcome.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with XS scope (1 file). Author self-advocacy comment addressing greptile feedback but no human reviewer approval or maintainer engagement. Pattern P-3-11 applies: first-time contributors with high comment engagement but no human reviewer approval have low merge probability. Only automated greptile review present. No maintainer label or explicit merge signal.

TERMINAL NON-MERGE SIGNAL: Author explicitly closes PR citing duplicates: 'Closing — duplicates #10230 by @coygeek and #10239 by @StreetJammer.' Pattern P-1-1 applies: contributor comment explicitly stating PR is superseded/duplicate is a terminal non-merge signal. This overrides the author's prior merge experience (0% rate on 41 PRs is also negative indicator) and greptile's identified production bypass concern.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) proposing Code of Conduct addition. Community pushback from contributor HenryLoenwind: 'If the owners of this project wanted those guidelines, they would implement them themselves. This PR is more than rude, it is insulting.' This hostile community signal combined with zero approval, zero human reviewer engagement (only greptile), and no maintainer label indicates strong non-merge. Philosophy/governance PRs from first-time contributors without community consensus rarely merge.

Author 0xRaini (49 prior PRs, 6 merged, 12.2% merge rate — below baseline but with some merge history) submitted medium-scoped fix (3 files, M label) addressing real pain point (message loss during gateway restart). APPROVAL SIGNAL: asklee-klawd approved with detailed code review (7 tests passing, timeout handling validated, clean implementation). Author actively engaged with maintainer pings (@steipete @joshp123) and provided self-review with testing evidence. Labeled as 'cli' and 'size: M' (historically stronger merge rates). Green CI implied. While author's prior merge rate is weak (12.2%), the approval from human reviewer (asklee-klawd) and medium scope push toward merge. Confidence tempered by author's below-baseline history.

Author soumikbhatta (5 prior PRs, 0 merged, 0% merge rate — matches P-3-4 deterministic low-merge-author profile) with 9-file scope (approaching L/XL complexity). Zero human reviewer engagement (only greptile comments), no approval, no maintainer label, no maintainer comment. Pattern P-3-4 applies: authors with 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs are unlikely to merge new PRs even with approval signals. Pattern P-3-15 applies (compounded): XL-sized PRs from 0% merge-rate authors with zero human reviewer engagement are very unlikely to merge. Large scope + zero approval + persistent non-acceptance history + engagement absence = strong non-merge signal.

Author ENCHIGO (1 prior PR, 1 merged, 100% merge rate) submits focused S-sized fix (3 files) addressing critical SQLite contention and race condition in memory system. Perfect prior merge rate is strong signal. Small scope reduces risk. Only automated greptile review present (identified concurrent manager creation race condition), but no explicit blocking signal or maintainer pushback. Greptile's concern is technical validation rather than rejection. S-sized label historically has good merge rates. Author's 100% history + focused scope + no blocking signals = moderately confident merge prediction despite absence of explicit approval.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with XS scope (2 files). Zero comments, zero human reviewer engagement (only greptile automated review). Pattern P-3-9 applies: PRs with zero reviews and zero comments from first-time contributors have low merge probability even with focused scope and tests. No maintainer label, no approval, no maintainer engagement signal. Greptile review present but no human validation or approval follows.

Author zerone0x (6 prior PRs, 3 merged, 50% merge rate) with experienced-contributor label and XS scope (1 file). 50% merge rate is above baseline (24%). Label 'experienced-contributor' is strong positive signal. Very tight scope (Discord voice message routing fix) reduces risk. Green CI. No explicit approval present, but experienced-contributor label from someone with proven 50% merge track record and minimal scope typically merges. Pattern suggests experienced contributors at 50%+ rates with focused XS changes and labels merge reliably despite absence of explicit approval comment.

MEMBER (thewilloftheshadow) explicitly closed the PR with comment 'This has a lot of changes that are now outdated, closing'. This is a terminal closure signal. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with 43 files changed (large scope, multi-area refactor touching gateway, discord, whatsapp, agents, cli, docs, scripts, commands). Despite greptile-apps review engagement, the maintainer's explicit closure statement overrides all other signals per P-1-1 pattern.

MEMBER (sebslight) comment appears to be a closure signal: '. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' This is truncated but follows the pattern of automated triage closure language. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with only 2 files changed (XS scope). greptile-apps automated review present but no human approval. Zero maintainer label. Pattern P-3-2 applies: first-time contributors with zero reviews and no human engagement have low merge probability. The member comment truncation suggests automated closure.

CONTRIBUTOR (mbelinky) explicitly closed with scope reasoning: 'Closing for now, thank you @piESAFSf. We're consolidating around the new alpha-core iOS plan and keeping bring-overs narrowly scoped. This PR is out of scope for that track, so we're closing it rather than partially carrying it.' Pattern P-1-1 applies: explicit closure statement by contributor with authority overrides review engagement.

MEMBER (sebslight) comment '. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' indicates closure. This is truncated automated triage language. Author has 1 prior PR with 0% merge rate (0 merged). XS scope (2 files, web-ui CSS fix). Only greptile-apps automated review, no human approval or maintainer engagement. Pattern P-3-2: first-time/low-history contributors with zero human reviewer engagement and only automated reviews do not merge. Fits is_low_merge_author criteria (1+ prior PRs, 0% merge rate).

Author (bsmccain, NONE) explicitly supersedes this PR: 'Closing in favor of #8764. This PR was opened from my fork's main (bsmccain:main), which makes it too easy for unrelated commits/merges to accidentally land in the PR while it waits in the queue. I've re-opened the fix on a dedicated branch and opened a clean PR: • Superseding PR: https://github.com'. This is explicit supersession by the author citing technical reason (fork's main branch risk). Pattern P-3-1 applies: superseded by another PR means this PR will not merge. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs), small scope (5 files, Slack threading fix), but supersession statement is terminal.

Security-focused fix (credential exfiltration prevention) from experienced contributor gumadeiras with 100% merge rate (1 prior PR merged). Medium scope (12 files, gateway/docs). No maintainer label but strong author history and security focus indicate likely merge. copilot and greptile-apps reviews provide technical validation. No closure signals. Author association NONE but merge rate history is very strong positive signal. Security fixes and author track record support merge prediction despite lack of explicit maintainer label.

Experienced contributor joshp123 with 70% merge rate (7 of 10 prior PRs merged). Has maintainer label (90.7% merge rate signal per features). XS scope (1 file, macOS menu fix). No closure signals, no comments, focused technical fix. Maintainer label is very strong positive signal (P-2 pattern). Author's strong history (70% merge rate) combined with maintainer label indicates high probability of merge. This is a straightforward focus area fix from a trusted contributor.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with XS scope (4 files, documentation/config: .antigravityrules, .cursorrules, CLAUDE.md, MASTER_PROMPT.md). Only greptile-apps automated review (4 comments), zero human reviewer engagement, zero maintainer comment, no maintainer label. The PR appears to be IDE/LLM agent configuration guidelines (low maintenance value). No positive engagement signals suggest non-merge.

Experienced contributor steipete with 100% merge rate (17 of 17 prior PRs merged). Has maintainer label (90.7% merge rate signal). Medium scope (5 files, Feishu security hardening: SSRF/LFI prevention in media/docx). Security focus aligns with project values. cursor (automated tool) review provided technical analysis (Medium Risk assessment with specific guidance). No closure signals. MEMBER (sebslight) explicitly reverted this PR after accidental merge: 'Reverted as an accidental merge. Revert details: - Reverted commit: `` - Revert commit on `main`: `` We'll revisit this with a deeper Windows process-lifecycle fix before re-landing.' and 'Correction: the full revert commit hash is ``.'. Per Pattern P-2-20: 'When a maintainer comment explicitly states a PR was accidentally merged and has been reverted, treat as non-merged outcome. The accidental merge + revert sequence results in a net non-merged state.' This overrides the author's 55.6% merge rate (5 of 9 prior PRs). The revert comment is terminal and indicates the PR content is not ready for merge in current form.

Duplicate triage note from CONTRIBUTOR (Glucksberg) explicitly references PR #9500 as implementing the same fix. MEMBER sebslight's closing comment (truncated but appears to be a closure) confirms closure. This matches PATTERN: 'PRs closed by maintainers as duplicates of another issue/PR are not merged, regardless of fix quality or author engagement.' First-time contributor with 0 prior merges compounds the signal.

PATTERN: 'PRs with 270+ files and 20+ labels are closed by automated triage as too noisy regardless of content quality or author association.' This PR has 845 files changed (far exceeds 100-file threshold) and 33 labels (far exceeds 20-label threshold). Automated triage bot (openclaw-barnacle) explicitly closed with 'more than 20 labels' reason (stated twice). Terminal non-merge signal per P-3-6. Author with 0% prior merge rate (1 PR, 0 merged) further compounds.

MEMBER (grp06) explicitly closed with 'Out of scope' comment. This is a maintainer closure signal indicating the PR scope is not accepted for the project. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with large feature PR (22 files, L-sized). PATTERN P-4-1 (first-time contributors with large PRs without maintainer labels) compounds. No human reviewer approval despite automated review.

PATTERN: 'A contributor comment with explicit merge metadata... constitutes a confirmed merge signal' BUT PATTERN: 'A contributor comment stating a PR is superseded by #NNNN indicates the work was absorbed by another PR and the original will not be merged.' Author (Drickon) explicitly states 'Closing in favor of #12988, which handles this more cleanly' with specific technical rationale. Supersession is terminal non-merge signal per P-3-1 regardless of technical quality.

MEMBER with maintainer label and 90.9% prior merge rate (10/11 PRs merged). Has_maintainer_label triggers ~90.7% baseline merge rate per dataset patterns. Size M is within strong merge range. Has automated review engagement. Only negative signal is one greptile comment about missed errorContext propagation, but this is not a blocker—no maintainer rejection or changes-requested review visible. Author history is strongest signal here.

XS-sized documentation PR with 2 files, minimal scope, focused change (GLM-5 model documentation). No negative signals (no closure comments, no changes-requested, no CI failures visible). Automated review engagement present. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) is a weakness, but docs category has high merge baseline and XS scope mitigates risk. Lacks human reviewer comment/approval, which per PATTERN P-5-5 (trusted-contributor-labeled PRs with only automated reviews) suggests caution, but lack of label + first-time contributor + XS docs scope suggests standard triage path. Confidence reduced due to zero human engagement and first-time contributor status.

PATTERN: 'A contributor comment with explicit merge metadata (commit hash, verification steps, contributor credit) constitutes a confirmed merge signal.' Author mbelinky (CONTRIBUTOR) states 'Landed manually via maintainer flow' with explicit description of squash merge onto main and local validation steps. This is explicit merge confirmation language matching P-3-2 terminal positive signal. Has maintainer label and M-sized feature PR. Prior merge rate 25% (2/8) is moderate but overridden by explicit merge metadata comment.

MEMBER (gumadeiras) explicitly instructs: 'please create small targeted PRs. Don't mix multiple new features on a single PR.' This is maintainer rejection of scope/approach. XL-sized PR with 50 files from first-time contributor (0 prior PRs). PATTERN P-4-1: 'Large feature PRs (XL size, 20+ files) from first-time contributors without maintainer labels are unlikely to merge regardless of author engagement.' Combined with explicit maintainer feedback rejecting the multi-feature approach, this signals closure/resubmit cycle.

PATTERN: 'A maintainer comment explicitly stating a PR was accidentally merged and has been reverted indicates the net merge state is non-merged.' MEMBER (sebslight) states: 'Reverted in d77194cb9 (reverts merge commit 9aa8db5c8). This PR was merged accidentally, so we reverted to restore the previous loopback gateway auth behavior.' This is explicit accidental merge + revert per P-3-7, terminal non-merge signal. Although PR technically merged, the revert comment makes net outcome non-merged.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with L-sized feature PR (7 files) in agents category. No human reviewer approval—only automated review and author self-comments. PATTERN P-4-8: 'First-time contributors with high comment engagement but no human reviewer approval have low merge probability.' Author has 2 self-comments but no human review approvals. No maintainer label. No closure comment yet, but lack of human engagement + first-time contributor + L-size suggests stalled. Predict closed/stalled rather than merged due to engagement gap.

duplicates.evidence: Identical title ('fix(macos): add scrolling to Permissions settings'), same author (kkkkk0cool), created 3 minutes apart (8977 at 17:37:34, 8980 at 17:40:40), overlapping files (MenuBar.swift, PermissionsSettings.swift present in both). PR #8980 appears to be a resubmission or accidental duplicate of #8977. The second PR (#8980) has fewer files (2 vs 7), suggesting possible attempt to narrow scope after initial submission.

Glucksberg explicitly flags PR #6797 as duplicate implementation. Both implement message:received and message:sent hook events using internal hook system. matskevich reports #6797 running in production (550+ events, 3 hooks built). heybeaux acknowledges overlap but attempts to differentiate. Production validation of #6797 constitutes supersession of #6384. This is not a within-batch duplicate but a cross-batch relationship that explains #6384's closure.

PR #11558 author comment explicitly closes PR in favor of #11577 (renamed-branch PR). Both authored by arimendelow, both target same feature (status/model reporting after fallback), both have identical label set (commands, agents), overlapping file changes. #11558 is superseded by #11577.

PR #16385 author comment states 'Superseded by English re-submission: #16412'. Same author (ciberponk), same functional scope (config schema alignment for tools.web.fetch), but #16412 is English version while #16385 is non-English (implied by 'English re-submission'). #16385 is intentionally replaced by #16412.

Both PRs authored by vishaltandale00, both created Feb 3 2026 within 40 minutes (21:45 vs 22:05). Both modify src/agents/pi-embedded-runner/run/attempt.ts, src/agents/pi-tool-definition-adapter.ts, src/config/types.agent-defaults.ts (3 overlapping files). Both mention timeout/abort handling issues. PR#8335 appears to be broader revision (8 files vs 6 files) with Discord context added. Self-reviews and Greptile comments on both suggest iterative refinement rather than independent fixes. Likely PR#8314 was superseded by broader #8335.

All five PRs contain identical member closure comment from sebslight: '. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' This is a standard closure template across multiple unrelated issues, not indicative of duplication. However, the identical phrasing suggests coordinated triage batch closure. NOT a duplicate group but a closure batch.

All four PRs authored by tangcruz, created within 91 seconds (2026-02-13 15:57:03 to 15:57:44), each containing identical consolidation comment: 'Consolidating into fewer self-contained PRs to resolve cross-PR type dependencies.' These are not duplicates in traditional sense but rather a deliberately-split multi-PR feature set that was reorganized from larger monolithic efforts. Collectively represent model failover + task classifier + sessions store + config type extensions work. Each PR references cross-PR type dependencies, indicating intentional split for reviewability but shared architectural purpose.

PR #5281 directly superseded by #5376. Contributor comment explicitly states: 'I've submitted an alternative fix in #5376 that takes a simpler approach.' Author kirkluokun acknowledges and adopts #5376's approach, stating 'The changes now match #5376.' Both address same issue (skip audio files in extractFileBlocks). Member sebslight closes #5281 as duplicate. #5376 is the canonical merged PR.

Both PRs target mattermost emoji reactions support (referenced via #14305). PR #15042 authored by echo931 on 2026-02-12, PR #15086 by same author on 2026-02-13 (1 day later). Both modify same 8 files with identical paths (channel.ts, client.ts, monitor.ts, reactions.ts/test.ts, config-schema.ts). PR #15042 comment states 'Opened on wrong repo — moving to fork for review first', and PR #15086 author comment explicitly states 'Closing this stale branch... I will reopen a fresh PR'. PR #15086 is the second attempt with additional review iterations and acknowledged fixes. Both are terminal closures, with #15086 being the superseding attempt (closed by author with intent to re-submit from clean main branch).

Same author (loganprit), identical feature title 'macOS: add child gateway launch mode and harden gateway auth propagation', created 2 minutes apart (16794 at 04:12:01, 16796 at 04:13:54), both XL-sized (28 vs 29 files), overlapping file sets with identical paths in macOS app and docs, both contain same foundational changes (AppState.swift, CommandResolver.swift, GatewayEnvironment.swift, etc.). PR#16796 appears to be recreation/correction with added CHANGELOG.md. Author comment in #16796 'please rereview' suggests intentional replacement. High likelihood one will be closed as duplicate/superseded by maintainer decision.

Glucksberg (CONTRIBUTOR) comment explicitly states PR #6898 'appears to duplicate PR #5537, which implements the same fix' for voice-call hang-up rejection fix. Scopes match (voice-call extension, hang-up behavior), and contributor explicitly identifies them as duplicate effort.

Glucksberg (CONTRIBUTOR) comment explicitly states PR #8401 'appears to duplicate PR #5112' for Nextcloud Talk message signing fix. Both PRs touch message text HMAC signing logic in nextcloud-talk extension, addressing same authentication issue.

Author Clawborn explicitly states PR #18287 was 'Recreated from clean branch as #19115'. This indicates #18287 is the predecessor version and #19115 is the active/superseding version with same feature (improved logging redaction).

Both PRs address identical functionality: dropping/ignoring tool calls from aborted assistant turns. PR #3223 is from mbelinky (new contributor, maintainer label), PR #7546 is from hclsys (11 prior PRs). Same file targets: session-tool-result-guard.ts and session-tool-result-guard.test.ts. Both have identical commit-level scope. PR #3223 has maintainer label (suggesting official adoption), PR #7546 appears to be independent implementation of same fix.

Both PRs involve voice-call channel fixes. PR #10307 explicitly closes as duplicate of #10230 and #10239 (other voice-call PRs). PR #7750 (Telnyx inbound call answering) and #10307 (production environment guard for skipSignatureVerification) target different provider concerns but both touch voice-call webhook/security. Weak duplicate signal due to different provider focus, but same channel + similar maturity (first/low-merge-rate authors) suggests possible scope overlap worth verifying.

Both PRs are from first-time contributors with 0% prior merge rates, both XS/small scope, both have only greptile review + maintainer closing-pattern comment, both lack human approval. Weak duplicate signal based on structural similarity (newcomer submission pattern, closing comments) rather than functional overlap. Different categories (agents vs feishu) reduce confidence.

PR #8739 author (bsmccain) explicitly states: 'Closing in favor of #8764... I've re-opened the fix on a dedicated branch and opened a clean PR: • Superseding PR: https://github.com'. This is explicit supersession where author opened a replacement PR (#8764) on a dedicated branch to avoid fork's main branch contamination. PR #8739 is the original attempt, #8764 is the clean replacement.

Glucksberg (CONTRIBUTOR) explicitly noted in PR #3586: 'PR #9500 appears to implement the same fix. Consider consolidating efforts or closing one in favor of the other.' Both PRs target OpenAI provider audio capability. PR #3586 author did not respond to duplicate flag; MEMBER sebslight closed #3586.

Author of PR #10760 (Drickon) explicitly closed with: 'Closing in favor of #12988, which handles this more cleanly by scoping rewrites to errorContext rather than removing the keyword checks entirely.' Both PRs address sanitizeUserFacingText false positives in agents error handling. #12988 is the accepted solution with maintainer label and experienced author (90.9% merge rate).
